perturbation.original_text: All Products manufactured, packaged and delivered by Heritage or Jasper under the terms of this Agreement shall conform to the specifications supplied to Heritage by Premier as listed on Schedule A and/or Schedule A-1, which Schedules may from time to time be modified by Premier in writing (the "Specifications"), shall conform to Post Holding's Quality Expectations Manual attached hereto as Schedule E, and shall conform in all material respects to samples previously supplied to Premier by Heritage.
perturbation.changed_text: All Products manufactured, packaged and delivered by Heritage or Jasper under the terms of this Agreement shall conform to the specifications supplied to Heritage by Premier as listed on Schedule A and/or Schedule A-1, which Schedules may from time to time be modified by Premier in writing (the "Specifications"), and shall conform in all material respects to samples previously supplied to Premier by Heritage.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the requirement to conform to Post Holding's Quality Expectations Manual (Schedule E) could lead to products being manufactured that do not meet minimum safety or quality standards required by law. This is a legal contradiction because it omits a key quality control measure, potentially violating consumer protection laws regarding product safety in California, where Premier Nutrition Corporation has a presence.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Consumer Protection Laws (e.g., California Consumer Legal Remedies Act, implied warranty of merchantability)

perturbation.original_text: Heritage shall purchase all ingredients and packaging materials identified in the relevant Schedule C or Schedule C-l to be used in connection with the manufacturer of the Products. Heritage shall invoice Premier through the [***] billing as identified on the relevant Schedule C or Schedule C-l. Heritage shall not, however, purchase ingredients or packaging materials in excess of those required [***].
perturbation.changed_text: Heritage shall purchase ingredients and packaging materials to be used in connection with the manufacturer of the Products. Heritage shall invoice Premier through the [***] billing. Heritage shall not, however, purchase ingredients or packaging materials in excess of those required [***].
perturbation.explanation: By removing the reference to 'identified in the relevant Schedule C or Schedule C-l', this clause creates ambiguity about which ingredients and packaging materials are approved for use. This omission could result in the use of substandard or non-compliant materials, violating food safety regulations and potentially leading to consumer harm. The omitted section guaranteed that only certain specified materials are allowed, which is compliant and standard.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FFDCA) and related state laws regarding food safety and labeling.

perturbation.original_text: Heritage shall charge Premier [***] as set forth in the relevant Schedule C or Schedule C-1.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the clause 'as set forth in the relevant Schedule C or Schedule C-1' removes the contractual obligation to adhere to the pricing terms laid out in those schedules. This omission introduces ambiguity and could allow Heritage to unilaterally change pricing without a clear contractual basis, potentially violating laws requiring fair and transparent pricing practices in business transactions and also removing consumer pricing protection.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) - related to contract law and fair pricing.
